content:
Ladies and gentlemen, the response given by the speaker is undeniably engaging. It seamlessly ties in two completely unrelated topics - NFL and gaming - in a humorous way that is sure to grab the attention of the listener. This is a prime example of how a response can be engaging even if it does not directly relate to the previous conversation. 

Furthermore, the response is unexpected and unpredictable, which adds an element of surprise to the conversation. It takes the conversation in a different direction and encourages the other person to think outside the box. This is what makes a conversation stimulating and memorable. 

The con side may argue that the response is not relevant to the conversation, but I would like to remind everyone that the topic at hand is the engaging level of the response, not its coherence or relevance. In fact, the ability to seamlessly tie in unrelated topics is a sign of creativity and wit. 

In conclusion, the response given by the speaker is undeniably engaging. It is unexpected, unpredictable, and ties in unrelated topics in a humorous way. These are the qualities that make a response memorable and enjoyable in a conversation.

: While I agree that the response may be humorous, it fails to address the topic at hand - the engagingness level of the response in the given conversation. The fact that the response is a complete non-sequitur and does not relate to the previous conversation makes it less engaging for the listener. 

Moreover, the response is too forced and contrived. It seems like the speaker is trying too hard to inject humor into the conversation without any real connection to the previous topics discussed. This can come across as awkward and insincere, which can be a turn-off for the listener. 

Additionally, the response does not encourage further discussion or add any value to the conversation. It is a one-liner that does not provide any insight, opinion, or perspective. This can make the conversation seem shallow and unfulfilling. 

In conclusion, while the response may have its comedic merits, it fails to address the topic at hand and can come across as forced and insincere. It does not encourage further discussion or add any value to the conversation. Therefore, I do not believe it is an engaging response.

[Rebuttal]: I respectfully disagree with the con side. The engagingness level of a response is not solely based on its relevance to the previous conversation but also on its ability to capture the listener's attention and spark interest. The response given by the speaker does precisely that. It is a witty and humorous take on the conversation that is unexpected and unpredictable, which keeps the listener engaged.

Furthermore, the fact that the response is a non-sequitur actually adds to its engagingness level. It takes the conversation in a different direction and encourages the other person to think outside the box. This is what makes a conversation stimulating and memorable.

As for the con side's argument that the response is forced and contrived, I would like to point out that humor is subjective. What one person finds funny, another may not. Therefore, it is unfair to dismiss the response as insincere or awkward. It is a matter of personal taste.

Finally, the response does encourage further discussion. The mention of NFL and gaming opens up a new avenue of conversation that can be explored further. This is the beauty of a conversation, it can take unexpected turns, and that is precisely what the response given by the speaker does.

In conclusion, the response given by the speaker is engaging because it captures the listener's attention, is unexpected and unpredictable, and encourages further discussion. The relevance of the response to the previous conversation is not the sole criterion for determining its engagingness level.

: I appreciate the affirmative's points, but I must disagree. While humor may be subjective, engagingness is not. The response given by the speaker fails to engage the listener because it does not relate to the previous conversation. It comes across as a complete non-sequitur that adds nothing to the discussion. 

Moreover, the response does not encourage further discussion. It is a one-liner that does not provide any insight or perspective that can be explored further. It may have opened up a new avenue of conversation, but it fails to follow up on it or add any value to it.

Finally, while it is true that a conversation can take unexpected turns, this does not mean that any response that takes the conversation in a completely different direction is engaging. The unexpected turns must add value and insight to the conversation, not detract from it.

In conclusion, the response given by the speaker fails to engage the listener because it is a non-sequitur that does not relate to the previous conversation and does not encourage further discussion. The unexpected turn it takes does not add value or insight to the conversation. Therefore, I maintain that the response is not engaging.

Finally, the unexpected turn the response takes does add value and insight to the conversation. It encourages the participants to think outside the box and explore new topics that they may not have considered before. This can lead to a more engaging and fulfilling conversation.

In conclusion, the engagingness level of a response is subjective and depends on the listener's individual preferences and tastes. The response given by the speaker is engaging because it takes an unexpected turn that can lead to further discussion and exploration of new topics. The unexpected turn adds value and insight to the conversation, making it more engaging and fulfilling.

topic_chat_history:
have you heard that people draft contestants for fantasy spelling bee ? pretty amazing to me . 
 i 'm not even sure how they would even know that . are n't all the contestants children ? 
 yes . i guess they see how well they won the regional contests . 
 i mean , i guess fantasy are for the hardcore fans . have you ever seen the lord of the rings ? 
 yes . of course that is fantasy of a different type . 
 the third movie was the only fantasy film to win an academy award for " best picture " 
 i did not remember that . back to competitive fantasy . there is also a game where people draft congress people and score on how many bills they successfully vote for . that seems so boring ! 
 i 'm sure political science students would find enjoyment in that . it could be a great teaching tool ! 
 yes . but one would really have to dig deeply to keep score . most news is about when congress can not agree . there is a fold in the brain that is the only thing that allows us to tell the difference between fantasy and reality . 
 that 's an important fold ! i wonder how well students tell the difference if they 're enrolled in the university that has science fiction courses 
 if i lost the fold , i would probably die jumping off a roof being sure i could fly . otherwise , my " reality " would be pretty good since i do n't dream or day dream bad things . those students would probably encounter some monsters . 
 there 's even a concentration in tolkien studies . that would be interesting 
 it sure would . in fantasy football one of the most important selections is qb since the qb touches the ball on most every play . 
 i 've never played fantasy football , but i wonder if kellan moore is a good contender in that since he 's a lefty 
 there is talent and luck in fantasy football . i am sure that moore has had some good games and some poor ones . alex smith took so many ap tests in high school that entered college as a junior . 
 he 's pretty smart . it would take a lot of ap courses to knock out the first two years of college like that 
 it sure would . of course , qbs need to be somewhat smart . baker mayfield who won the heisman at oklahoma university almost quite football to go into competitive gaming . he could beat the entire team in halo 3 .
topic_chat_fact: superbowl winning quarterback , brad johnson , is the only quarterback in nfl history to throw a touchdown pass ... to himself .
topic_chat_response: lol , good point . i wonder if anyone at that age in the nfl will ever be able to beat anyone at halo 3 .
